steps.lesson:
FEWD 21 Typing Speed Test

Topics covered in this walkthrough

We've gone through this assignment in class so in the first steps so we assume the basic funcionality is implemented. Beyond that:

  • Add sentences with increased difficulty.
  • Attach onclick handler to a group of buttons and determine which one sent the event.
  • Use jQuery.index().
  • Validate user input against original sentence prompt.
  • Use a form to enable submit by pressing [enter] key.
  • Add realtime analysis of typing speed as user types.
  • Abstract common logic into resuable functions.

How to Follow Along

The tutorial shows step by step code changes. Removed code is red while added code is green. Navigate the steps by the orange back and forward arrows -- the keyboard arrows work as well.

Test and run the code yourself at any time by downloading the source, then clicking "View File" on the top right of the code to copy that file's contents at that given step.

Code Source

  • Github
  • Download .zip

diffs.content:
Welcome to the Typing Test!

  • Click on the Start Test button
  • Type the phrase that appears in the orange box into the light green box as fast as you can
  • Click on the DONE! button. Your results will be displayed at the bottom of the page


You typed X words in Y seconds, a speed of about Z words per minute!

© Footer Goes Here

steps.lesson:
Add completed javascript from in class lessons.

This is the base functionality that uses only one sentence.

diffs.html:
1 + $(document).ready(function() {
2 + var startTime;
3 +
4 + $("#start-easy").click(easyTest);
5 + $("#donebutton").click(finishTest);
6 +
7 + function easyTest() {
8 + $('#prompt').val('lorem ipsum sic dolor');
9 + startTime = new Date();
10 + }
11 +
12 + function finishTest() {
13 + endTime = new Date();
14 + var userText = $("#usertext").val();
15 + var totalTime = Math.round((endTime - startTime)/1000);
16 + var words = userText.split(' ');
17 +
18 + var typingspeed = Math.round(words.length/totalTime * 60);
19 +
20 + $('#resulttext').html(
21 + 'You typed '+ words.length + ' words in '
22 + + totalTime + ' seconds, a speed of about '
23 + + typingspeed +' words per minute!'
24 + );
25 + }
26 + });

steps.lesson:
Add increased difficulty sentences.

The easy test should use the first (easiest) sentence by default.

diffs.html:

2 2 var startTime;
3 + var prompts = [
4 + 'lorem ipsum sic dolor',
5 + 'The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog and I followed in kind',
6 + 'To go into solitude, a man needs to retire as much from his chamber as from society. I am not solitary whilst I read and write, though nobody is with me. But if a man would be alone, let him look at the stars.'
7 + ];
8 8
9 9 $("#start-easy").click(easyTest);
10 10 $("#donebutton").click(finishTest);
11 11
12 12 function easyTest() {
8 - $('#prompt').val('lorem ipsum sic dolor');
13 + $('#prompt').val(prompts[0]);
14 14 startTime = new Date();
15 15 }
16 16

steps.lesson:
Add a click handler to all buttons by grouping them into a #difficulty element.

Now every button is clickable. Additionally, there is no longer an explicit need for ids on each of the buttons.

steps.lesson:
Use the index position of the buttons within their parent to determine which prompt to show.

Google thought process: "jquery get index of element"

Result: http://api.jquery.com/index/

diffs.html:
10 10 $("#donebutton").click(finishTest);
11 11
12 12 function setDifficulty() {
13 - $('#prompt').val(prompts[0]);
13 + var promptIndex = $(this).index();
14 + $('#prompt').val(prompts[promptIndex]);
15 15 startTime = new Date();
16 16 }
17 17

steps.lesson:
Validate that the user's input matches the given prompt.

We need promptIndex in order to know which sentence difficulty to compare to so we need to give it a more global scope.

Note: It is possible to grab the sentence again using $("#prompt").val() but this treats the DOM like a database and it is yet another jquery lookup (performance consideration). We have the data in pure javascript (not in the DOM) so we should use that whenever possible.

steps.lesson:
Add support for submit by enter key

After the user is done typing, it's annoying to have to use the cursor to manually click the button.

The easiest way to support a native 'submit event' when the user presses enter is to wrap the button in a form. Since we really don't want to actually submit the form e.preventDefault() is used within the form submit event. Lastly we need to call the finishTest() logic.

diffs.content:
Welcome to the Typing Test!

  • Click on the Start Test button
  • Type the phrase that appears in the orange box into the light green box as fast as you can
  • Click on the DONE! button. Your results will be displayed at the bottom of the page


You typed X words in Y seconds, a speed of about Z words per minute!

© Footer Goes Here

steps.lesson:
Realtime results

Let's make it even better by providing realtime results as the user types.

As the user types 'keypress' events are emitted. We will listen to this event and display our results.

However, the function finishTest() validates the input which will always be false as the user is typing. =/

Google thought process: "jquery event when user types"

The results are not spot on but the first one does point to the keyup event (I used the more generic keypress).

Always remember to also check/browse the documentation: http://api.jquery.com/category/events/.

steps.lesson:
To get out of the forced comparison logic within finishTest() we need to decouple the typing speed processing logic from the 'finishTest' logic.

Create a more standalone getTypingSpeedOutput() function that can be reused.
